i18nValue.NL_NL: B2 is out, B3 is up.  Runners get to advance because of the passed ball, but the double is nullified (B3 is removed).  One run total scores.

i18nValue.EN_US: B3 is out, B2 is up.  All plays nullified.  No runs score, all runners return to their original bases.
i18nValue.NL_NL: B3 is out, B2 is up.  All plays nullified.  No runs score, all runners return to their original bases.

i18nValue.EN_US: B2 is out, B3 is up.  All plays nullified.  No runs score, all runners return to their original bases.
i18nValue.NL_NL: B2 is out, B3 is up.  All plays nullified.  No runs score, all runners return to their original bases.

i18nRuling.EN_US: 7.03(b).  All plays as a result of the improper batter batting are nullified.  All plays that occurred *before* the batter became a runner stand.
i18nRuling.NL_NL: 7.03(b).  All plays as a result of the improper batter batting are nullified.  All plays that occurred *before* the batter became a runner stand.

i18nValue.EN_US: Batting order B1, B2, B3, B4.  B2 is the proper batter, but B3 comes up to bat.  1st pitch gets by the catcher, all runners advance (R3 scores).  B3 then hits a clean double, scoring the remaining 2 runners.  Defense appeals that B3 is out of order, before any more plays are made.  Sort this mess out.
i18nValue.NL_NL: Batting order B1, B2, B3, B4.  B2 is the proper batter, but B3 comes up to bat.  1st pitch gets by the catcher, all runners advance (R3 scores).  B3 then hits a clean double, scoring the remaining 2 runners.  Defense appeals that B3 is out of order, before any more plays are made.  Sort this mess out.

i18nValue.EN_US: False

i18nRuling.EN_US: 7.08(a)(1) - The runner is out when he runs more than 3 feet away from a direct line between the bases to avoid being tagged.  Here, the shortstop has no chance at a tag, so the runner is not avoiding a tag.  Therefore, the runner is not out.
i18nRuling.NL_NL: 7.08(a)(1) - The runner is out when he runs more than 3 feet away from a direct line between the bases to avoid being tagged.  Here, the shortstop has no chance at a tag, so the runner is not avoiding a tag.  Therefore, the runner is not out.

i18nValue.EN_US: The shortstop has the ball very far from the runner advancing from second base to tag him.  The runner zig-zags 6 feet to each side of the base line.  As he retreats to second.  He is out for running out of the baseline.
i18nValue.NL_NL: The shortstop has the ball very far from the runner advancing from second base to tag him.  The runner zig-zags 6 feet to each side of the base line.  As he retreats to second.  He is out for running out of the baseline.

i18nValue.NL_NL: Noone scores.  R1 is out.  Game over.

i18nValue.NL_NL: Everyone scores.  R1 is not out.  Game over.

i18nRuling.EN_US: 7.10(d) "...the appeal must be made before all the defensive players have left fair territory"  All the defensive players left fair territory.  They forfeited their right to appeal.  All runs score, game over.
i18nRuling.NL_NL: 7.10(d) "...the appeal must be made before all the defensive players have left fair territory"  All the defensive players left fair territory.  They forfeited their right to appeal.  All runs score, game over.

i18nValue.EN_US: Bottom of the 6th.  Down by 2 runs.  Batter knocks one out of the park.  R1 is so excited, he misses 3rd base.  Everyone leaves the field before the defensive manager starts shouting at everyone to appeal.  The players run back on the field.  The pitcher, with the ball, steps back from the rubber with his pivot foot and announces he wants to appeal that R1 missed 3rd base.  When the crowd finally quiets down, what do you do?
i18nValue.NL_NL: Bottom of the 6th.  Down by 2 runs.  Batter knocks one out of the park.  R1 is so excited, he misses 3rd base.  Everyone leaves the field before the defensive manager starts shouting at everyone to appeal.  The players run back on the field.  The pitcher, with the ball, steps back from the rubber with his pivot foot and announces he wants to appeal that R1 missed 3rd base.  When the crowd finally quiets down, what do you do?

i18nRuling.EN_US: 2.00 "Fair ball"  The ball was touched while it was in fair territory.  It is a fair ball.  The ball is never judged by the position of the fielder, only the position of the ball
i18nRuling.NL_NL: 2.00 "Fair ball"  The ball was touched while it was in fair territory.  It is a fair ball.  The ball is never judged by the position of the fielder, only the position of the ball

i18nValue.NL_NL: Fly ball is touched in fair territory by a fielder standing in foul territory

i18nValue.EN_US: False
i18nValue.NL_NL: False

i18nValue.EN_US: True
i18nValue.NL_NL: True

i18nRuling.EN_US:
7.05(g) - If it is the first play by an infielder (and *all* runners have not yet advanced a base), runners get 2 bases from the base they were on at the time of the pitch.  Otherwise, all runners get 2 bases from the base they legally held at the time of the throw. 

Often people believe this is "the base they were going to plus one", but consider a runner diving back to the bag on a pick off.  If the ball goes out of play, what's the award?  They were "going [back] to the base", so don't they only get the next base?  This is a case where the words we use can be interpreted wrong by a manager. The rule is clear -- two bases from the last legally held base.
i18nRuling.NL_NL:
7.05(g) - If it is the first play by an infielder (and *all* runners have not yet advanced a base), runners get 2 bases from the base they were on at the time of the pitch.  Otherwise, all runners get 2 bases from the base they legally held at the time of the throw. 

Often people believe this is "the base they were going to plus one", but consider a runner diving back to the bag on a pick off.  If the ball goes out of play, what's the award?  They were "going [back] to the base", so don't they only get the next base?  This is a case where the words we use can be interpreted wrong by a manager. The rule is clear -- two bases from the last legally held base.

i18nValue.EN_US: When a fielder throws the ball out-of-play, the runners are awarded the base they were going to plus one.
i18nValue.NL_NL: When a fielder throws the ball out-of-play, the runners are awarded the base they were going to plus one.

i18nRuling.EN_US: 6.06(b).  Batter is out for illegal action when stepping from one batter's box to the other while the pitcher is in the position ready to pitch.

i18nRuling.EN_US: 6.08(b).  Exception (1) The ball is in the strike zone when it touches the batter…it shall be called a strike.  Approved ruling:  When the batter is touched by a pitched ball which does not entitle that batter to first base, the ball is dead and no runner may advance.
i18nRuling.NL_NL: 6.08(b).  Exception (1) The ball is in the strike zone when it touches the batter…it shall be called a strike.  Approved ruling:  When the batter is touched by a pitched ball which does not entitle that batter to first base, the ball is dead and no runner may advance.

i18nValue.EN_US: Pitcher delivers a strike right down the middle.  The batter's elbow is hit over the plate while he turns away from the ball.  The ball bounces away from the catcher while R1 advances to 2nd base.  Sort it out.
i18nValue.NL_NL: Pitcher delivers a strike right down the middle.  The batter's elbow is hit over the plate while he turns away from the ball.  The ball bounces away from the catcher while R1 advances to 2nd base.  Sort it out.

i18nValue.EN_US: False
i18nValue.NL_NL: False

i18nValue.EN_US: True
i18nValue.NL_NL: True

i18nRuling.EN_US: 2.00, Quick Return. Do not allow a pitcher to pitch when the batter is not alert and paying attention. If a pitcher's pace is naturally too fast, slow him down by giving him the count audibly, step away, etc.  (Don't hold up you're hand -- this implies "Time" and a dead ball).  If the batter is taking too long to get set, announce "Let's go batter" and get ready for a pitch -- you've given him due warning a pitch is coming.
i18nRuling.NL_NL: 2.00, Quick Return. Do not allow a pitcher to pitch when the batter is not alert and paying attention. If a pitcher's pace is naturally too fast, slow him down by giving him the count audibly, step away, etc.  (Don't hold up you're hand -- this implies "Time" and a dead ball).  If the batter is taking too long to get set, announce "Let's go batter" and get ready for a pitch -- you've given him due warning a pitch is coming.

i18nValue.EN_US: The count on the batter is two balls and two strikes. The pitcher delivers ball three to the batter and the catcher throws the ball back to the pitcher. While the batter is adjusting his/her batting glove the pitcher toes the pitcher’s plate and fires strike three. The manager of the offensive team argues that this is a quick return pitch and should not be allowed. The umpire rules in favor of the defense – strike three.
i18nValue.NL_NL: The count on the batter is two balls and two strikes. The pitcher delivers ball three to the batter and the catcher throws the ball back to the pitcher. While the batter is adjusting his/her batting glove the pitcher toes the pitcher’s plate and fires strike three. The manager of the offensive team argues that this is a quick return pitch and should not be allowed. The umpire rules in favor of the defense – strike three.
